Fault detection with new trains is expected during early stages of production & service. During this phase, we employ a high level of scrutiny to proactively address any potential issues & optimize performance for a more efficient release of future Red & Orange Line trains.

Sanyi was a dedicated T member, serving riders since 2011. Known to many as Keni or Kenitra, she was beloved by her twin children, 3 sisters, extended family, friends, & colleagues. As the Harris family mourns their great loss, we ask that you keep them in your thoughts.

On February 8, we tragically lost a member of our MBTA family. Bus Operator Sanyi K. Harris passed away after an accident at the Quincy Center busway. We extend our sincerest condolences to all those who knew, loved, & worked with Sanyi, & wish them peace in this difficult time.

We know asking our riders for more patience and understanding is a considerable request, and it's one we take to heart. That is why the breadth and depth of work planned for this year strives to improve service for many years to come. Visit: http://mbta.com/BBT2020

During the diversions, we'll provide alternate service to keep our riders moving and will coordinate with all our partners, local and state, to support and prioritize these initiatives. We pledge to communicate with our riders clearly and consistently each step of the way.

We‰Ûªll utilize diversions on weekends and weekdays to make more significant progress sooner. Planned closures now mean fewer unplanned disruptions in the future. These closures grant us full access, allowing us to complete a year‰Ûªs worth of night work in about a month.

#BuildingABetterT is our commitment to make the T a better, safer, and more reliable public transit system - one befitting of our riders and the communities we serve. Building on the work and lessons learned in 2019, we‰Ûªve outlined the scope of work we aim to accomplish in 2020.

But our work doesn't stop here. It‰Ûªs not just about repairing the damage, it‰Ûªs about #BuildingABetterT. For the Red Line, we‰Ûªre: - Investing $350 million for signal system upgrades - Spending $470 million for track & maintenance - Delivering 252 new, modern cars

We are grateful to our riders for understanding the enormity of this task and for bearing with us through it all. We are thankful for everyone who labored to maintain Red Line service and to restore it to its full capacity.

Our crews rebuilt: - 3 signal bungalows + a new bungalow - 20 miles of signal cable - Hundreds of signal control relays This means we're back to the standard 28 trains at rush hour running every 4-5 mins, automatic switching, & countdown clocks with real-time predictions.

We know this has been a trying few months for our Red Line riders. That is why we are pleased to announce the full restoration of service as of September 23. The Red Line is now back to its pre-derailment service levels across the Line - on both the Braintree & Ashmont Branches.

These fixes allow us to add 8 more trains into service, bringing the peak total back to 28 and increasing the overall rider capacity by about 18,000 people. Trains still need the ‰Û÷okay‰Ûª to move from one station to the next, so trains may stand by in stations.

21 of 29 signals & 11 of 19 switches are back to being remotely controlled by our Operations Control Center (part 2) and no longer need to be set by hand (part 1). This shortens the time it takes to set routes & helps to speed up the process of getting you where you need to be.
At this time, 3 signal bungalows (the sheds housing our signal hardware) have been rebuilt and 1 additional bungalow was built for extra power and communications support.

Bus is a lower fare then subway. Some may not transfer.
A pass is go for unlimited travel during the month.
If you take the bus first, $1.70 will deduct from your card, then $0.70 when entering the subway, which totals $2.40.
A transfer is available for up to 2 hours from your first tap. Your card will deduct $2.40 when you tap into the subway - nothing will be deducted when taking a local bus within that 2 hour window.
Do you normally use a LinkPass, CharlieCard or ticket for your commute?
No. You only get charged the difference from bus to subway - when/if you reverse commute (bus, then subway).

And with a CharlieCard or a CharlieTicket, you can make a free transfer at Airport Station from the Blue Line to SL3 (or from the SL3 to the Blue Line).
And there‰Ûªs an instance where you can make 2 transfers, too! If you‰Ûªre going from Local Bus to subway to Local Bus, with a CharlieCard you‰Ûªll pay just 1 subway fare.
With a CharlieCard you can always transfer from subway to Local Bus. And if you transfer from Local Bus to subway, you‰Ûªll only pay the difference in fare.

You might already know that our monthly LinkPass offers unlimited travel on subway and Local Bus. But if you put cash value on you CharlieCard or CharlieTicket, there are many transfers you can make within 2 hours of your first boarding! http://mbta.com/transfers

Your safety is our first priority, so in addition to regular Red Line safety assessments, we are conducting a comprehensive assessment of the entire fleet. All vehicles that are the same type as the car that derailed have been inspected.
As for the cause of the derailment, we‰Ûªve ruled out operator error, speed, foul play, and track issues. We‰Ûªre currently investigating the vehicle that derailed.

Our plan is to replace the existing analog signal system with a new digital system. This work was already planned, but upgrades will now start at JFK/UMass. You can learn more about it at http://mbta.com/signals
Throughout the summer, the signals at JFK/UMass will be rebuilt, and service will improve incrementally as work is completed.
#RedLine Update: As of today, we‰Ûªre able to safely run about 10 Red Line trains an hour (compared to about 14 an hour before the derailment).

Southbound passengers desiring Braintree service, will still need to switch trains at JFK/UMass - same with northbound passengers coming from Braintree. This will continue as repairs are made to the signal system.
We are continuing to work on signal repairs, as well as previously planned investments in signal upgrades at JFK/UMass. We will update you here and on our website at http://mbta.com/redlineservice

Until then, the folks at our Operations Control Center are in constant contact with operators, dispatchers, and inspectors out in the field, providing location and arrival info for system alerts and more.
We know what a pain this is, and while we can‰Ûªt get data from the signals at JFK/UMass, we‰Ûªre working on using the data we get from other stations to bring back predictions along the Red Line.
That‰Ûªs why, if you‰Ûªre waiting at Park Street for a northbound train to Davis, you might not see arrival predictions in minutes, even though it‰Ûªs outside of the signal data gap.

Normally, when a northbound train passes through Broadway, the signal data helps predict its arrival at the next few stations based on typical travel times. Since we aren‰Ûªt getting that data from Broadway Station, our system can‰Ûªt predict arrival times at the next few stops.

This is effective and safe, but not as efficient as automatic data updates. It also means that we‰Ûªre not receiving the signal data that informs arrival predictions for stations on the rest of the line

The damage to the signals at JFK/UMass created a data gap between Broadway and Fields Corner. While the signals are being repaired, we have crews out in the field communicating with the Operations Control Center about train locations.
It also informs our real-time data, which we use for in-station countdown clocks, our website, and 3rd-party apps like Google Maps and Transit. This is what those signals usually looks like.

That hardware takes in data from the signal infrastructure along the tracks, and sends it out to places like our Operations Control Center, where dispatchers monitor trains traveling through the system.
Earlier this week, we mentioned that the derailment damaged the signal bungalows at JFK/UMass that house the hardware for our signal system.

Repairs to the tracks and 3rd rail at JFK/UMass are now complete, but trains are still moving slowly through the station, and you might be wondering why we‰Ûªre not able to give specific arrival times on our website and in-station countdown clocks.

We‰Ûªve made sure Wellington‰Ûªs in great shape to test the new cars, but we‰Ûªre also making sure Wellington is the facility it needs to be to keep our new cars successfully performing well into the future. Learn more about the Wellington improvements here: https://www.mbta.com/projects/orange-line-improvement-program

Wellington‰Ûªs maintenance facility was built in the ‰Û÷70s & needed modernizing. We completed installation of 4 new bridge cranes & a new hoist with more service bays & new diagnostic equipment to come. The Wellington Yard is also getting new track, power, signals, & repair tech.

Since we‰Ûªll be increasing the number of cars in our Orange Line fleet to 152, we recently completed the addition of six brand new storage tracks at Wellington. The new tracks help us move trains through the yard and help with storing trains when they‰Ûªre not in service.

If you‰Ûªve passed through Wellington recently, you may have seen new Orange Line cars being tested on the expanded test track. We‰Ûªre gearing up to put them into service in mid-summer & that can only happen thanks to over $200mill in ongoing upgrades at Wellington‰Ûªs facilities.
